section.title: How To Find A Concept
section.para: Users may want to search for concepts to see concept details, pertinent relationships, and associated authoring information.

listitem.para: To find a concept, first, either open a new journal or utilize an open and existing journal, then, select the magnifying glass icon in the left-hand bar
Type the keyword or concept name into the search bar at the top of the left-hand panel to find a concept ()

Results containing the keyword will populate in the field below the search bar. You can also use a "+" symbol in front of each word and a space to separate each "+[word]" when you know exactly what concept you are searching for to return only exact matches (e.g., +meaty +pizza)
To view a concept, double click on a search result, drag the concept to the center panel, or right click a concept and select "Populate Concept"
You can click the magnifying glass icon in the left-hand bar again to minimize the search panel for more space (this can be done for any icon in the left-hand bar)
Toggle the "Properties" button on and use the icons at the top right-hand side of the concept window to view various details and information about the selected concept ()
The concept window can display additional information, including:
Identicons
STAMP information
Identifiers
Description Semantic with Language and Dialect
EL++ Stated terminological axioms showing hierarchical relationships

Note: The bottom half of the axiom section are the concept's defining characteristics that the concept's author or editor defined. The top half of the axiom section are the concept's defining characteristics that the reasoner defined, this may include additional concepts
To view hierarchical relationships, select the Navigator icon in the left-hand bar and expand the desired concepts by selecting the arrow next to each one ()
In this example, we will find various pizzas by expanding Model Concept, Pizza Builder Knowledge Base Concept, Food, and then Pizza

Alternatively, if you have a concept already open and would like to see where that concept lies in the hierarchy, you can go to the desired concept window, go to the Axioms section and drag the desired concept into the Navigator panel
Inferred navigation pattern information will appear on the left-hand side, as seen in below
Hierarchical Relationships can also be viewed in the center panel by toggling the "Properties" button on and selecting the "Hierarchy" icon at the top of the concept window ()
Utilize the arrows within either Hierarchical Relationships panel to collapse or expand relationships, as needed
Finally, you can view Hierarchical Relationships by clicking the pop-out icon in the Axiom section of the concept window as seen in below

section.title: Viewing Versioning
section.para: Users may want to view concept versioning to understand how a concept has evolved over time, including when certain characteristics or details were added or removed and when axiom changes were made.

listitem.para: To view versioning, either open a new journal or utilize an existing and open journal, and follow the steps to view a concept in
In the tool ribbon at the top left of the concept window, click the Time Travel button, which is highlighted in green in below
The Timeline panel opens to the right. The blue and purple lines in the Timeline panel represent different data extensions.
Click the ellipsis in the top right of the Timeline panel to see additional information on the Path and Extensions that the timelines represent ()
Toggle the "Properties" button on in the top right of the concept window
Then toggle the "Range" button on ()

Drag the top or bottom horizontal blue bars to view concept version information over a specified date range. When you define a specific time range, the History view will only show event details for event nodes within that time range (our pizza example was modeled in a day, so events are limited)
Selecting a specific node on the timeline will turn the node green and highlight information pertaining to that change or concept version ()
You can further narrow the versioning by selecting the "All" drop down arrow to filter historical events by Concept, Description, and Axiom changes ()

section.title: Creating a Concept
section.para: Users may want to create a concept to represent new or emerging information or create temporary concepts while Standards Developing Organizations create official representations. Creating a concept allows users to enter associated information like Status, Time, Author, Module, and Path (STAMP), stated relationships, and more
A major component of each concept is their respective axioms. Axioms are accurate and truthful statements that help define a concept

For example, to help define a pepperoni pizza the pepperoni pizza concept may have, but is not limited to, the following axioms;
Is a pizza
Has a topping of pepperoni
Has a topping of cheese

listitem.para: To create a concept, first open a new journal or utilize an existing and open journal, and click the "+" icon at the top of the Komet window and select "New Concept" ()
A new concept template will appear ()

To add STAMP properties of the new concept, select the STAMP box in the top right of the concept window and select the options within each drop down menu to add the appropriate information for STAMP()
In general ():
Primordial Modules and Paths should be used for starter datasets
Development or Sandbox Modules and Paths should be used for unvetted data changes
Master Paths should be used for data changes that have been vetted by organizations as complete and tested
For this example, we use the Development module and Development path, but the Pizza Knowledge Base Module is also appropriate
Select Confirm
Select the pencil icon on the right-hand side of the description section of the concept window to add a description ()
Select "Add Fully Qualified Name" and fill out the requested information seen in below
When complete, scroll to the bottom of the panel and select "Submit"
Select the pencil icon again on the right-hand side of the description section to add an Other Name, as needed ()
Finally, select the pencil icon on the right-hand side of the axiom section of the concept window to add axiom information, including sufficient and necessary sets ()
For this example, select "Add Sufficient Set"

Note:
A necessary set is a set of relationships that is always true of a concept
For example, a Pepperoni Pizza is a Food
A sufficient set is a set of relationships that differentiate a concept and its subtypes from all other concepts
For example, a Pepperoni Pizza is a pizza with only pepperoni and cheese toppings
Once you add a Sufficient or Necessary Set, it will appear in the Axioms section ()
After a Sufficient or Necessary set is added, a unique identifier will also automatically be generated for your concept ()
Your concept will then appear in the concept search bar on the left-hand side ()
To further define your concept, you will need to add information about your concept in the axiom section ()
To begin, we will remove an automatically populated role group by selecting the pencil icon next to the blue anonymous concept role group and select "Remove Axiom". We will discuss role groups later
Next you select the pencil icon next to your orange Sufficient Set in the axiom panel and select "Add is-a" ()
An anonymous concept will appear in the axiom. Select the pencil icon next to the anonymous concept and select "Choose replacement is-a" and then "Search for concept" ()
Find a concept to provide additional information about your concept
In this example, we want to say the T.O.M pizza is a named pizza, so search for "Named Pizza", press enter, and then double click the desired concept ()
Next, select the pencil icon next to the sufficient set and select "Add Role Group" ()
In the role group, within the Orange section, select the pencil icon, "Choose role type", and then "Search for concept" to add additional information about your concept ()
Here, we are saying that the T.O.M pizza will be defined, in part, by its toppings, so we will search for and add a "Has Topping" concept ()
Next, we will clarify what topping helps to define the T.O.M pizza
In the role group, within the Orange section, select the pencil icon, "Choose role restriction", and then "Search for concept" ()
For this example, we will add the "Tomato Topping" to the T.O.M Pizza by searching for Tomato Topping, pressing enter, and double clicking the desired concept ()
The role group will automatically update to reflect the information you have populated ()
We will repeat these steps to add "Has Topping" role groups for onions and mozzarella. Please see above to repeat these steps
At this point, it is advised to run the reasoner. Please see
Once the reasoner has run, you will need to exit out of the concept you just created and search for it using the next-gen search feature

Once you re-open your concept, the top portion of your concept's Axioms section will be automatically populated. It may contain concepts that you did not define in the bottom axiom section, as the reasoner logically organizes the concept (this may include classifying your pizza as other larger pizza categories, like margherita as seen in below)
You can then drag your new concept from the top Axioms section into the Concept Navigator to view the hierarchical organization ()

section.title: Editing a Concept
section.para: Users may want to edit or modify a concept to reflect new and emerging real-world data or real-world evidence.

listitem.para: To edit a concept, first open a new journal or utilize an existing and open journal, and find the concept you want to edit, double-click or drag the concept into the main viewing window, and toggle the "Properties" button on

Note, if you are editing a concept you just created, you must first exit out of the concept window, find the new concept with the search feature, and then double click or drag the new concept back into the viewing window
To edit STAMP information and to create a new version of a concept, click on a STAMP and update either Status, Module or Path and select Submit ()
After updates are made, the STAMP will be updated to reflect the changes and the Author who performed the change ()
Any changes will be reflected in the History Tab as well()
You can then directly edit a Fully Qualified Name or Other Name by clicking the respective name in the concept window ()
You can also select the "Add/Edit" pencil icon at the top right of the concept viewing window ()
Selecting "Edit Description" leads to two additional options ()
Selecting "Edit Fully Qualified" allows you to edit the selected concept's Fully Qualified Name and associated information ()
Selecting "Add Other Name" allows you to add a new description of the concept and associated information ()

Once you have changed the Fully Qualified Name or added an Other Name, scroll to the bottom of the edit panel and select submit. You can also write a comment to provide additional information on the changes.
We can also edit existing role groups, such as changing the Tomato Topping to a more specific Sun Dried Tomato Topping () ()

figure.title: Changing a Concept in the Axiom

listitem.para: After making any edits, it is advised to run the reasoner. Please see

section.title: Creating and Editing a Pattern
section.para: Users may want to create or edit a Pattern to provide additional, important information to a concept. Depending on the data set and existing concepts, users may need to create additional concepts that help define parts of the pattern or to actually create the pattern itself
In this example, we will need to create the following concepts to help define a Cooking Instruction pattern

table.title: Concepts to Create for Pattern Creation and Editing

listitem.para: To create a new pattern, first open a new journal or utilize an existing and open journal, and click the "+" icon at the top of the Komet window and select "New Pattern" ()
A new pattern editing window will appear, where you can select the ellipsis to add STAMP information()
Next, select the Pencil Icon in the Pattern Definition section to add Semantic Purpose and Semantic Meaning )

Concepts for both Semantic Purpose and Semantic Meaning can be found by using the search bar within the Pattern window or by selecting the Comment Icon on the left-hand bar and searching for desired Concepts to define what our Pattern will do
For this example, we want to create a pattern that provides the cooking instruction information so we know how to cook our pizza
To do so, we will need to create the below concept for "Cooking Instructions" to add to the Purpose and Meaning sections ()

Users can then search for the Cooking Instructions concept in the Purpose and Meaning search bar or drag-and-drop the concept into the Pizza Cooking Instructions Pattern Purpose and/or Meaning from the next-gen search, as seen in below

figure.title: Cooking Instructions Pattern Purpose and Meaning

listitem.para: Once you have added concepts for Semantic Purpose and Semantic Meaning, click "Done" in the Properties panel
Next, select the Pencil Icon in the Description section to add a Fully Qualified Name and/or Other Name ()

Selecting "Add Fully Qualified Name" or "Add Other Name" opens the Properties panel for users to fill out various components of a Pattern's description. For this example, we will name the pattern the "Cooking Instructions Pattern" ()

figure.title: Cooking Instructions Pattern Fully Qualified Name

listitem.para: Once all necessary components are complete, select "Done"

Before you add Fields to a pattern, you may need to create concepts to represent the Field's Purpose and Meaning. For this example, you will need to create the following three concepts for "Oven Type", "Temperature", and "Cooking Equipment" ()()()
Once you have created these concepts, you will use them to add three Fields to the Cooking Instructions Pattern
Select the Pencil Icon in the Fields section of the Cooking Instructions Pattern to associate additional information with the pattern and select "Done" when all information is added for the Field ()
Create the following three fields using the "Component Field" data type
Once you have added the requested information for a Field, click "Done". You may then select "Add another field" or "Close panel", as needed
Note: The Display Name for each Field will automatically populate once the meaning field has been defined () () ()

When adding Fields to a pattern, you may need to add a data type depending on the pattern. The following list highlights some potential options:
Data Types for Patterns and General Semantic Authoring
Data Type Description
String Any alphanumeric text
Integer Any whole number
Float Any decimal or whole number
Boolean True/False
Component Can be a concept/pattern/semantic/STAMP
Component Set
Can be a set of concepts/patterns/semantics/STAMPs.
Does not allow duplicates.
Component List
Can be a list of concepts/patterns/semantics/STAMPs.
Does allow duplicates.
Image Currently supports JPG, PNG, BMP, GIF images
If needed, you can edit Fields by right clicking the desired Field Number in the Fields Section and selecting "Edit" ()
Once all sections have been completed for the Pattern, select the Globe icon to save the pattern ()

If completed properly, an identifier will be generated underneath the Pattern name in the concept window and the Pattern will appear within the list of Patterns that can be accessed by selecting the Concept Navigator icon on the left-hand bar and then Patterns ()

section.title: Creating and Editing a Semantic
section.para: Users may want to create or edit a semantic to associate important information with a specified concept. Semantics can only add information that is outlined by a specific pattern, for instance the oven type, cooking equipment, and temperature needed to cook a specific pizza.
Depending on the data set and existing concepts, users may need to create additional concepts to create a semantic

For this example, users will need to create concepts for Pizza Oven, Pizza Stone, and 420 Fahrenheit to fill out the information needed to complete the Cooking Instruction Pattern Concepts to Create for Creation and Editing a Semantic
Concept Is-A
Pizza Oven Oven Type
Pizza Stone Cooking Equipment
420 Fahrenheit Temperature
To create a semantic element, open the concept navigator panel on the left-hand side and select "Patterns". Locate the pattern you would like to create a semantic element for, right click, and select "Add New Semantic Element". In this example, we will use the Cooking Instructions Pattern ()
New Semantic Element
A New Semantic window will appear for the specific pattern you choose ()
New Cooking Instructions Semantic
Select the ellipsis in the top right-hand side to enter STAMP information for this semantic ()
Cooking Instructions Semantic STAMP
Next, select the pencil icon on the right-hand side of the Reference Component section to associate this semantic with a specific concept ()
New Reference Component
You can use the Next Gen-Search on the left-hand tool bar or you can type free text into the search field to find the concept of interest. For this example, we will drag-and-drop the T.O.M Pizza concept into the Reference Component. Once you have added the Reference Component, select "Confirm"
Once the Reference Component is added, the pencil icon in Semantic Details will become available, which you should select to add the necessary Pattern Fields ()
New Semantic Details
For this example, we will need to create the following three concepts to add to the "Oven Type", "Cooking Equipment", and "Temperature" Fields, respectively () () ()
Pizza Oven Concept
Pizza Stone Concept
Temperature Concept
Once all three concepts have been created, use the Next Gen-Search on the left-hand tool bar, search for each concept, and drag-and-drop that concept into the appropriate Field in the Cooking Instructions Pattern ()
Semantic Fields
Click "Submit" and the semantic will be complete ()
T.O.M Pizza Cooking Instructions Semantic
You can also view the semantic by going to the concept navigator panel on the left-hand side, selecting "Patterns", locating the pattern of choice, and expanding the "Semantic Elements" tab ()
Semantic Viewing

section.title: Exporting Datasets
section.para: Users may want to export a dataset to share some of their authoring work with other users

listitem.para: To export a dataset, first open a new journal, or in an existing and open journal select "File" in the upper left-hand side of the application window and select "Export Dataset" ()

Complete all of the necessary fields, including Time Period. Time Period can be any changes made during the Current Date or can be changed to a Custom Range to export changes made during a specific time period ()
Once you have entered all pertinent information, click "Export" and a progress bar will appear in the bottom left-hand side of Komet ()

section.title: Importing Datasets
section.para:
Users may want to import a dataset to view changes or authoring done by other users
To import a dataset, first open a new journal, or in an existing and open journal select "File" in the upper left-hand side of the application window and select "Import Dataset"
Once the following pop-up opens, drag your desired dataset into Komet or browse for the specific files and click "Import". The dataset must be a .zip file type ()
Import Dataset
Once you select "Import", a progress bar will appear in the bottom left-hand side of Komet ()
Importing

section.title: Git Sync
section.para: Users may want to use Git Sync to connect to their GitHub account in the Komet application so they can pull and sync change sets to a repository that they have created. To collaborate, Git Sync can allow a user to contribute change set(s) to others and integrate changeset(s) from others.
Menu Options:

listitem.para: Info - Just connects to GitHub without pulling or syncing any changesets.
Pull - Pulls the change sets from the Git Hub repo that the connection was made with, loads them into Komet and then automatically runs the Reasoner.
Sync - Pulls the change sets from the repository, loads them into Komet, runs the Reasoner, and then pushes the changesets to the repository.

section.para: To get started, you will need to be signed into your personal GitHub account. If you do not have an account, create one at GitHub

listitem.para: Next, create a Personal Access Token (PAT), which is a secure alternative to your password when authenticating, by logging into your GitHub account, selecting your user icon in the top right-hand corner of the page and selecting "Settings". Instead of entering your password in Komet, you will use the PAT, which is a unique, long string of characters, to authorize your actions ()
Now go to "Developer Settings" ()
Select "Personal access tokens" ()
Select "Tokens (classic)" ()
From the Generate New Token drop down, select "Generate new token (classic)" ()
You will now be prompted to enter your password or authentication

You will need to enter a note (this note should help you differentiate this token from other similar tokens), under "Select scopes" select "repo", and then select "Generate token" at the bottom of the page () ()
You will then be redirected to your newly created token, where you should copy and save the token number (using the copy icon next to the passkey) for a later step ()

section.title: Creating a Repository
section.para: Users will need to create a repository (repo) in their personal GitHub account to pull or sync change sets from Komet to GitHub ()()

listitem.para: Select your user icon in the top left corner and navigate to "Your repositories"
Select "New" to create a new repo

You will then need to name the repo (it is suggested to choose a name that will help identify the work you are doing), choose if you would like it to be a "Public or "Private" repo, and select "Add a README file" before selecting "Create Repository" ()
Select the green "Code" button and, from the drop down menu, ensure "HTTPS' is selected. Then copy the repository web address and save for a later step ()

section.title: Using Git Sync
section.para: There are several functions of Git Sync that a user may want to use in Komet;

listitem.para: Info - Connects Komet to GitHub without pulling or syncing any change sets
Pull - Pulls the change sets from the GitHub repo that the connection was made with, loads them into Komet and then automatically runs the Reasoner.
Sync - Pulls the change sets from the repository, loads them into Komet, runs the Reasoner, and then pushes the change sets to the repository.

To use Git Sync Info, first open a new journal with the desired database you would like to use to generate a change set. The Komet landing page will open and the GitHub Status will show as disconnected ()
Select "Exchange" in the top left-hand side of the application window and select "Info" ()

Fill in the various fields that appear in the Info window and then press "Connect"; Git URL is the URL we saved in an earlier step, Git Email is the personal email you used to create your GitHub account, Git User Name is the personal GitHub username that you created, and Git Password is the repository passkey that we saved in an earlier step ()
When done correctly, you will see the GitHub Status showing as "Connected" with a progress popup window appearing ()
Once connected to the repo, select option to “Trust Now” ()

To use Git Sync Pull, first open a new journal with the desired database you would like to use to generate a change set. From the landing page, select "Exchange" in the top left-hand side of the application window and select "Pull" ()
Any change sets that were in the GitHub repo will then be pulled into Komet and a progress popup will appear ()

To use Git Sync Sync, first open a new journal with the desired database you would like to use to generate a change set. From the landing page, select "Exchange" in the top left-hand side of the application window and select "Sync" ()
Note, you will need to complete the steps outlined in Git Sync Info first
You will see the below popup while the Sync processes ()

To ensure the Sync completed successfully, go to the repository you created earlier to validate that the change sets were successfully completed. This process can take a minute or so, as the change sets are pushed to GitHub
Validating Change Sets in Repository

section.title: Running the Reasoner
section.para: Users may want to run the pertinent reasoner to update the inferred relationships—based on the author's stated relationships for a concept—to update the Hierarchical Relationship tab in the left-hand bar, to detect equivalences, and more.
Note: If you run into issues running the reasoner, fully close out of Komet and re-open the application. This may include opening your task manager and ending the application process

listitem.para: To run the reasoner, first open a new journal or utilize an existing and open journal, then open the Reasoner panel by selecting the Reasoner icon in the left-hand tool ribbon ()
Select the drop down menu in the top left of the Reasoner panel and select "Run Reasoner" ()
The reasoner may take up to a few minutes to successfully run, but you should see a reasoner progress bar appear in the bottom left-hand side of the Komet window ()

Once finished, the reasoner will generate results in the Reasoner Results tab. Results include concept size, cycles, orphans, and equivalences. These equivalences can then be expanded to see the specific equivalent concepts. ()
You can then compare the equivalent concepts by control+clicking on each concept, right clicking, and choosing "Compare Concepts" ()
This will then open all of the concept windows to allow users to understand the similarities and differences of each concept and action, as needed ()
